titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Federal Theatre Project Posters, approximately 1935-1939
titlestmt.author: Inventory prepared by Laura Streett

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Laura Streett, 2010.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Federal Theatre Project Posters

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

did.abstract: Posters advertising Federal Theatre Project productions, mostly in New York City, but also in Chicago, Boston, San Diego, San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Long Beach, California. There are also three posters advertising productions of the Federal Music Project.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Federal Theatre Project was sponsored by the Works Project Administration. It ran from 1935-1939 and was directed by Hallie Flanagan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Posters advertising Federal Theatre Project productions, mostly in New York City, but also in Chicago, Boston, San Diego, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Long Beach, California. There are also three posters advertising productions of the Federal Music Project.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research according to the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library without any additional restrictions.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to quote (publish) from unpublished or previously published material must be obtained as described in the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection may have been gathered by Hallie Flanagan, but there is no verifying documentation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Federal Theatre Project Posters, Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries.
